body: @dependabot rebase
@dependabot rebase
I would like to contribute to this issue.

Finally a PR. Great! 
~~I don't currently have the bandwidth to build this, but if someone can provide a build to test with, i'd be happy to do so!~~

Actually looks like that tag produced the artifact/build for us. Here is the link: 
https://github.com/apache/netbeans/suites/15927621533/artifacts/909562610
No reply in ~9months, closing.

> I guess there is an argument that NB19 is a previous version if you're using a daily build though?!

yep. that would indicate regression in master. But its not so important, text can be edited afterwards.

@lkishalmi #6369 is not ready yet and I had no time to take another look after the initial attempt.

its another case where dependencies where not kept up to date for a while.
![图片](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/12583400/1cdc70af-c45f-41ec-83b0-5520aef556ff)
Many operations can cause  “background scanning project..” and then system is very slow.

Good call on the exception and retry.

> Might be good to extract the logic to a utility method and use it from both call sites.

Which logic?  I would be wary of using the retry loop there, unless there's a check it's in the RP thread first.
Check the location of the cache directory in `Help / About`.  Close NetBeans, delete the cache directory, and restart.  Does that help?

> JDK
>
> Tried with many, but I guess it is using the one packaged in the snap

There is no JDK packaged in the Snap.  It should use the `javac` location found on the path, although I'm not 100% sure if the Snap packaging messes with that logic at all.  What does `javac -version` give you?

Not sure how you're passing `--jdkhome`?

If you do want a self-contained version with a packaged JDK runtime, check the community deb or appimage.

Good call @matthiasblaesing !  Any chance you could try with and without your changes on your work machine with the Robot test code from https://github.com/apache/netbeans/issues/3962#issuecomment-1664507172 ? 

I'm curious if the above is the issue why reports say it never resolves and people need to restart the IDE though.

@neilcsmith-net tried the code and it does not show a problem, but I also only saw it only occasionally in the past. 

It would be good if the people, that regularly experience the problem, could try this test build:

- Checkpage: https://github.com/apache/netbeans/actions/runs/6126503420
- Direct link: https://github.com/apache/netbeans/suites/15975431445/artifacts/912247352

If it does not help, it might show if this is the right location to look at, as at least it improves logging around the problematic location. We should then see evidence in the log.

Edit: I also can't answer why the problem is persistent for some, as I could only observe the blocked Clipboard while my test code was running, afterwards, the IDE reacted normally again.

Removing cache directory seems to have improved ，i found ,netbeans run:

https://stackoverflow.com/q/6583642/14731 contains excellent answers that should allow us to log which process is at fault. @matthiasblaesing Perhaps you could incorporate it into your PR.

> 
> > Might be good to extract the logic to a utility method and use it from both call sites.
> 
> Which logic? I would be wary of using the retry loop there, unless there's a check it's in the RP thread first.

the call is known to randomly fail. If retry mitigates the issue it is worth to consider it there too. How often and with what delay (possibly without delay!) can/should be tweaked once confirmed that this is fixing the issue.

We should also check how long a failing call takes. Since a succeeding call can take ~100ms. So retry + sleep might take longer than expected. (maybe we have luck and a failing call returns immediately in which case we don#t have to worry about that)

@bradvido unfortunately that stack trace appears to be the previously not suppressed message in SetContents at https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/master/platform/o.n.bootstrap/src/org/netbeans/NbClipboard.java#L460 Interestingly that already has retry built into it, stemming from https://bz.apache.org/netbeans/show_bug.cgi?id=139616

I don't think you need to change the logging level to see @matthiasblaesing change, and probably better not to do so as we know it affects the issue already.

@mbien just saying that line 206 might be in the EDT, so sleeping for a second if the clipboard is permanently inaccessible is possibly a bad move.

Just noticed from the stack trace shared in the issue that `NbClipboard.SetContents` already has a continuous retry by rescheduling itself.

this dev https://github.com/apache/netbeans/suites/15975431445/artifacts/912247352 version does not change bug's behavior, please provide some very basic instructions on how to create valuable logging feedback, what to look for. I guess @bradvido's test code is sufficient to provide this feedback.

@bradvido could you share the full message.log for the test run? Not sure if it really helps, bug something might turn up. Neil is correct, the trace you are seeing comes from the NetBeans -> notepad copy, not the notepad -> NetBeans one. It would also be interesting to do a run without enhanced logging, as @neilcsmith-net suggested.

@istinnstudio I'm not sure what to look for. The thing that PR #6428 changes is, that one of the cases where the system clipboard is accessed now can't fail silently. The logging is on level INFO, so should be always in the message.log

> It could even turn out that NB is locking itself out by calling the system function from too many threads too often.

I've wondered about this too. Although there aren't that many possible threads, and as far as I can tell the access in the JDK is thread safe.

There is also a flag which should be turning off the background thread behaviour, and most affected users who've tested that have reported it not helping.

I wish the IDE logging had time stamps for each line it prints to console, wouldn't it be helpful?  is it possible? Then we could add time stamps to @bradvido's code and see if anything valuable comes out

To change the logging format, you'll need to change the code:

https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/f3bbe321592be090fe3c0a4ebf9a6107a3f69fcd/platform/core.startup/src/org/netbeans/core/startup/logging/NbFormatter.java#L56-L98

Unfortunately at the moment I do not have a system ready to compile source code or use git to pr. But if you like, in a next "debug" release we could include log time stamps. You could add a very simple pr with:

`import java.text.SimpleDateFormat;`

after line 41
`private static final SimpleDateFormat dateFormat = new SimpleDateFormat("HH:mm:ss.SSS dd-MM-yyyy"); // Timestamp`

after line 57
```
    // Append timestamp
    sb.append(dateFormat.format(new Date(record.getMillis()))).append(" >> ");
```


maybe then we could link those INFO events to something that make sense with the test script.

EDIT: Please provide the full message.log of the run. The full log might span multiple files, please check if that is the case.

> Would it be so wrong to still support macOS 10.x?

Does Apple?!

> I assume in the app-package there should only be a netbeans wrapper binary "Contents/MacOS/netbeans" that can be run on macOS 10.x too.

With NetBeans 19 we swapped to using NBPackage to build the macOS installer.  This builds the Swift launcher in `Contents/MacOS` as a universal binary when no local JDK is included (as we cannot from ASF). As part of that change https://github.com/apache/netbeans-nbpackage/pull/32 the minimum macOS version was raised from 10.13 to 11.

I think in theory we could build the x86_64 aspect against a lower macOS version, but that would complicate the process.  A PR might be accepted, but it would have to cover all three possible combinations of architecture cleanly and not cause complications.  I'm not sure if it's worth the effort?

If you need to use NetBeans 19 on macOS 10.x you're stuck with the zip distribution.

took me a while to realize that the "..." button transforms into a dropdown button which opens the special buttons popup and that mouse buttons don't automatically resolve into a value when you press edit.

But I think it works. I mapped `MOUSE_BUTTON6` and `7` which is forward/back on my mouse to comment and uncomment and it worked. Tried the same with 4/5 which are mouse wheel left/right and it worked too. Using logitech G502 which has a few buttons.

(what confused me initially was that `xev -event button | grep button` uses different button numbers than java does, so either the linux distribution or java must map them somehow)

btw what is the forward/back action?

> took me a while to realize that the "..." button transforms into a dropdown button which opens the special buttons popup and that mouse buttons don't automatically resolve into a value when you press edit.

Yes. Have added a screenshot of this to the description.

> (what confused me initially was that `xev -event button | grep button` uses different button numbers than java does, so either the linux distribution or java must map them somehow)

Confused me for a while with `xev` too.  I realised that X11 is mapping the mouse wheel up/down as buttons 4 & 5, so these are skipped in Java's button numbering.

Think it's explained by the code at https://github.com/openjdk/jdk/blob/master/src/java.desktop/unix/classes/sun/awt/X11/XWindow.java#L731  As is why we need to use the mouse pressed rather than mouse clicked events (not generated for higher numbered buttons).
 
> btw what is the forward/back action?

An editor action, also in the editor toolbar.  Try `CTRL-click` on a method to open another method in the same or a different file.  Now try the back button (or in NB19 `ALT-LEFT`).  It's a multi-level navigation history - very useful when exploring code across multiple files.

@istinnstudio the logs look like a clean run (from the NetBeans side at least). The content is right, the call to set the content in the clipboard does not fail, so from our end all looks fine. Even if the setting would fail, it is not expected, that it is empty.

For your questions: the "Last record repeated again" message is an optimization from netbeans (not sure whether I agree with this):

https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/f48f91e6c197d8a40bd82fc2f2d12a4e71242afe/platform/core.startup/src/org/netbeans/core/startup/logging/MessagesHandler.java#L187-L200

This also explains the timestamp difference as the new message is synthesized later than the original message. 

Your testcode does not show what is in the clipboard when it fails. It might be completely empty or just unsupported flavors, it might reveal something if you output that.

If that does not show more, I'm inclined to cleanup the "repeat fetch" commit from my test branch and get that in. That might already fix cases and maybe we are looking at an artificial problem here.

> For your questions: the "Last record repeated again" message is an optimization from netbeans (not sure whether I agree with this):

It should be configurable though - https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/master/platform/core.startup/src/org/netbeans/core/startup/logging/MessagesHandler.java#L68

Not tested, but I assume `-J-Dorg.netbeans.log.disableRepeatingMessagesFilter=true` will work to stop it and get accurate timestamps if any use.

However, yes, no smoking guns in the log(s) by the look of it.

Makes sense to keep the distinction then, or at least `GetContents` as you have it (possibly with a comment).  It could be worth considering the same change in `SetContents`.  That task is also waited on in a few places, and I wonder if there is any point where that might be a problem.

@alcarraz your two locations look the same above! 

You can create a secondary `netbeans.conf` in the userdir (wherever that is with the Snap). For other packages at `~/.netbeans/19/etc/netbeans.conf`.  Add a single line with the location of your desired runtime JDK.

`netbeans_jdkhome="/path/to/jdk"`

I'd also note that NetBeans IDE stopped supporting running on JDK 8 with NetBeans 13.  The platform stopped supporting it with NetBeans 19, which is why you're getting the new message now.  NetBeans 22 will drop support for JDK 11.

@istinnstudio you are looking at the wrong value. The clipboard owner is the application, that copied data into the clipboard, but it is most probably not the application, that is our actual problem. The problem is, that to get access to the clipboard you need to call [`OpenClipboard`](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-US/windows/win32/api/winuser/nf-winuser-openclipboard). While the introductions reads as if multiple readers could open the clipboard in parallel, this is invalidated in the remarks, so this is an exclusive lock. So we have to look at all clipboard users (readers and writers), but the clipboard owner is just the writer.

To get the reader you should be able to use [GetOpenClipboardWindow](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-US/windows/win32/api/winuser/nf-winuser-getopenclipboardwindow). It might be interesting to see which process is reported from there. However the clipboard might be opened without an associated window, in that case you'll receive NULL, whether the clipboard is opened or not.

I have a brend new Netbeans 19 and JDK 17 I can't believe the cache is corrupted in two days...
"java.util.zip.CRC32C cannot be found on the system module path"

@roberto-cisternino check if you have an invalid value for `jdk.home` as discussed above.  If not, open a separate issue, with your log attached.

4,8 is the latest release which is on maven central.
https://mvnrepository.com/artifact/org.apache.netbeans.utilities/nbm-maven-plugin

The snapshots are not released, they can also disappear without warning:
https://repository.apache.org/content/repositories/snapshots/org/apache/netbeans/utilities/nbm-maven-plugin/

You shouldn't use the snapshot repository in most cases, unless you are testing staged builds of upcoming releases for example.

What we should do however is to filter snapshot releases from the new project wizard so that it doesn't upgrade the version to unreleased artifacts. I remember doing this in other wizards, this one must have slipped through.

> @roberto-cisternino check if you have an invalid value for `jdk.home` as discussed above. If not, open a separate issue, with your log attached.

While I had jdk17 my project source/target was 11 so I solved by using 17

            <plugin>
                <groupId>org.apache.maven.plugins</groupId>
                <artifactId>maven-compiler-plugin</artifactId>
                <version>3.11.0</version>
                <configuration>
                    <!--source>11</source-->
                    <!--target>11</target-->
                    <release>17</release>
                </configuration>
            </plugin>
Thanks for the adjustments! Looks good!
